awd_titl_txt: Compressive ultrahigh-speed imaging beyond trillions of frames per second using spatiotemporally encoded metasurfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
Capturing ultrafast phenomena in their actual time of occurrence plays a central role in the discovery of new scientific principles and the development of new technologies. For example, the abilities to monitor transient molecular states using the pump-probe spectroscopy have provided new insight into chemical reactions. The premise for a typical pump-probe method is that identical phenomenon will be induced by identical pump pulses, affording the opportunity to study it repeatedly. However, many ultrafast phenomena are either non-repeatable or irreversible, and thus they cannot be imaged using the conventional pump-probe techniques. Compact, affordable, and single-shot ultrafast imaging technology beyond trillions of frames per second remains an unmet need for the observation of non-periodic and irreversible transient events. Merging an artificially engineered synthetic surface, called metasurface, and the compressive sensing technology, the research aims to develop a compact, metasurface-enabled, single-shot imaging system for capturing the dynamic properties of ultrafast phenomena and uncovering the unknown or hidden laws that govern such dynamics. The program will closely integrate diverse research, teaching, and outreach activities together to enhance photonics education infrastructures at the university and will form a unique platform that will make broad impacts on human resource and education. The proposed research will also generate opportunities at both the college and K-12 levels and the related results will be used for designing exhibitions for local educational events. 

The overarching goal of this research program is to integrate two cutting-edge technologies – the optical metasurface and compressive sensing – together to develop a compact, cost-effective, single-shot imaging system enabling ultrahigh-speed imaging beyond trillions of frames per second. The system can be used for capturing the dynamic properties of ultrafast phenomena and uncovering the unknown or hidden laws that govern such dynamics. Empowered by the metasurface – a synthetic surface consisting of subwavelength-sized elements (meta-atoms) that locally engineer the electromagnetic response on the nanoscale – the ultrafast imaging system encodes the incoming optical information using a metasurface-enabled “pixelized” encoder both in space and in time. The encoded information is then captured by a normal camera. By leveraging the compressive sensing algorithm and the high temporal resolution of the metasurface encoder, a three-dimensional ultrafast movie revealing information in (x, y, z, t) dimensions is computationally reconstructed for an ultrafast non-periodic event, which is previously not possible.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our project focused on developing a novel single-shot imaging technique to capture ultrafast events – phenomena that unfold over trillionths of a second (femtoseconds to picoseconds). Traditional methods for studying such rapid processes often require scanning multiple time delays, which can be impractical or impossible when observing non-repeatable events. By contrast, our approach uses a judiciously designed metasurface combined with advanced computational algorithms to obtain a full-time sequence of an ultrafast event in just one camera exposure.

A key scientific achievement was the design and fabrication of a spatiotemporal encoding metasurface. This device consists of many tiny, engineered pixels, each introducing a slightly different optical time delay. When an ultrafast laser pulse passes through or reflects off this structure, each part of the beam experiences a unique time delay. We then developed a mathematical reconstruction algorithm, based on the Alternating Direction Method of Multipliers (ADMM), to transform a single snapshot into a detailed “movie” of the underlying fast process. This approach was validated through both numerical simulations and experiments for monitoring the reflectivity of a semiconductor saturable absorber mirror (SESAM), an optical component that undergoes extremely rapid reflectivity changes when illuminated by a strong laser pulse.

By combining nanofabrication techniques (like three-dimensional printing on the nanoscale) with state-of-the-art ultrafast laser systems and algorithmic innovations, our project pushed the boundaries of what is currently achievable in time-resolved imaging. The resulting method addresses an important technological challenge: how to observe, in real time, events that last only a few femtoseconds without relying on complex scanning hardware or multiple shots of the same process.

Beyond its immediate applicability in ultrafast optics, our technique opens doors to diverse fields that rely on capturing transient or short-lived events. Researchers in materials science can use it to watch real-time phase transitions, while those in biophotonics might study rapid biological changes. Because the method relies on a single shot, it is especially well-suited for non-repeatable phenomena – ranging from fast chemical reactions to certain extreme-environment experiments.

Equally important, this project fostered the professional growth of multiple doctoral students. By designing, fabricating, and testing nanophotonic devices, as well as developing advanced computational methods for image reconstruction, these students gained valuable, interdisciplinary expertise. Through conference presentations and collaborative efforts, they further strengthened their communication and project-management abilities, positioning them for leadership roles in academia or industry.
